newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-AUSTRALIA TRANSPORT-Industry wants stronger say in planning.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-AUSTRALIA TRANSPORT-Industry wants stronger say in planning.

text.p: Australia's tourism industry is seeking a stronger voice in transport planning, urging government backing for private sector infrastructure projects.
"Tourism has never been given a seat at the transport planning table and that ought to change," Tourism Task Force lobby group chief executive Christopher Brown told Reuters.
While little quantitative work had been done on the impact of transport projects on tourism, their importance was clear, particulary in a country the size of Australia, Brown said.
"It's one thing to get people to this island continent...but we've got tourism product all over the country, so we have to move them around," he said.
Transport was also the key to encouraging regional development and broadening the tourism base.
"If we're going to spread the dividend into the bush, then we need to physically do it by transport," he said.
The number of international visitors to Australia is expected to top the four million mark in 1996, and grow nine percent a year through to 2005.

Domestic tourism has grown more moderately in recent years, but is expected to increase at between two and three percent a year over the next five to ten years, according to a recent report by the Tourism Task Force.

The A$80,000 study on tourism transport needs, funded by government and industry, recommended the development of a national database of transport infrastructure projects and reforms to boost private sector involvement.
Brown said the report revealed there was no long-term view on transport, despite the huge number of potential projects.
He said planners should be looking ahead by 10 or 20 years and thinking in terms of strategy rather than on a project-by-project basis.
Brown said it was also clear governments were unable to commit the necessary funds to public transport infrastructure, and should look to foster private funding.

This could be done by maintaining infrastructure bonds, which offer a tax break to private investors, and providing a one-stop-shop approach for developers and financiers to stop bureaucratic duplications.
Governments should also constantly review planning and approval processes to remove any unnecessary regulations.
"The government ought to become proponents of these projects ...they ought to be working with the private sector to attract investment," said Brown.
The report found Australia was well served by air transport, but recommended that government free-up access to Australia on a regional basis.
Tourist travel on roads was seen as part of total travel demand, while Australia did not have the population to support a comprehensive national rail system.
However, a number of discrete rail projects were planned and the government should develop a national strategy for the industry, the study said.
Cruise shipping was seen as a potential growth area, given the worldwide boom. "That's one area where we can actually grow a market based on new infrastructure," Brown said.
Governments could also aid the industry by reform of port charges, as well as navigation regulations and fuel excise and duty.
The report identified and analysed 13 transport projects which it said were of national importance, while another 150 were submitted to the authors.
Some of these projects included the Sydney to Canberra high-speed rail proposal, a highway project in Western Australia's Kimberley region and cruise ship terminals in Cairns and Darwin.
However, it warned that Australia's attraction as an investment destination was diminishing as other countries, particularly the growing Asian economies, began to compete for funds.
